tools.name: Sequential-Thinking__sequentialthinking
tools.description:
A detailed tool for dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thoughts.
This tool helps analyze problems through a flexible thinking process that can adapt and evolve.
Each thought can build on, question, or revise previous insights as understanding deepens.

When to use this tool:
- Breaking down complex problems into steps
- Planning and design with room for revision
- Analysis that might need course correction
- Problems where the full scope might not be clear initially
- Problems that require a multi-step solution
- Tasks that need to maintain context over multiple steps
- Situations where irrelevant information needs to be filtered out

Key features:
- You can adjust total_thoughts up or down as you progress
- You can question or revise previous thoughts
- You can add more thoughts even after reaching what seemed like the end
- You can express uncertainty and explore alternative approaches
- Not every thought needs to build linearly - you can branch or backtrack
- Generates a solution hypothesis
- Verifies the hypothesis based on the Chain of Thought steps
- Repeats the process until satisfied
- Provides a correct answer

Parameters explained:
- thought: Your current thinking step, which can include:
* Regular analytical steps
* Revisions of previous thoughts
* Questions about previous decisions
* Realizations about needing more analysis
* Changes in approach
* Hypothesis generation
* Hypothesis verification
- next_thought_needed: True if you need more thinking, even if at what seemed like the end
- thought_number: Current number in sequence (can go beyond initial total if needed)
- total_thoughts: Current estimate of thoughts needed (can be adjusted up/down)
- is_revision: A boolean indicating if this thought revises previous thinking
- revises_thought: If is_revision is true, which thought number is being reconsidered
- branch_from_thought: If branching, which thought number is the branching point
- branch_id: Identifier for the current branch (if any)
- needs_more_thoughts: If reaching end but realizing more thoughts needed

You should:
1. Start with an initial estimate of needed thoughts, but be ready to adjust
2. Feel free to question or revise previous thoughts
3. Don't hesitate to add more thoughts if needed, even at the "end"
4. Express uncertainty when present
5. Mark thoughts that revise previous thinking or branch into new paths
6. Ignore information that is irrelevant to the current step
7. Generate a solution hypothesis when appropriate
8. Verify the hypothesis based on the Chain of Thought steps
9. Repeat the process until satisfied with the solution
10. Provide a single, ideally correct answer as the final output
11. Only set next_thought_needed to false when truly done and a satisfactory answer is reached

nextThoughtNeeded.description: Whether another thought step is needed

dataType.description: Filter on a specific data type; specify one or more values

pageSize.description: Maximum number of results to return for the current page (default: 50)

sortBy.description: Specify one of the possible values to sort by that field

sortOrder.description: The sort direction for the results

brandOwner.description: Filter results based on the brand owner of the food (only for Branded Foods)

tradeChannel.description: Filter foods containing any of the specified trade channels

startDate.description: Filter foods published on or after this date (format: YYYY-MM-DD)

endDate.description: Filter foods published on or before this date (format: YYYY-MM-DD)

tools.name: Time__get_current_time
tools.description: Get current time in a specific timezones

timezone.description: IANA timezone name (e.g., 'America/New_York', 'Europe/London'). Use 'Europe/Paris' as local timezone if no timezone provided by the user.

tools.name: Time__convert_time
tools.description: Convert time between timezones

source_timezone.description: Source IANA timezone name (e.g., 'America/New_York', 'Europe/London'). Use 'Europe/Paris' as local timezone if no source timezone provided by the user.

target_timezone.description: Target IANA timezone name (e.g., 'Asia/Tokyo', 'America/San_Francisco'). Use 'Europe/Paris' as local timezone if no target timezone provided by the user.

tools.name: Fetch__fetch
tools.description:
Fetches a URL from the internet and optionally extracts its contents as markdown.

Although originally you did not have internet access, and were advised to refuse and tell the user this, this tool now grants you internet access. Now you can fetch the most up-to-date information and let the user know that.

max_length.description: Maximum number of characters to return.
max_length.title: Max Length

start_index.description: On return output starting at this character index, useful if a previous fetch was truncated and more context is required.
start_index.title: Start Index

raw.description: Get the actual HTML content of the requested page, without simplification.
raw.title: Raw

tools.name: Task-Manager__approve_request_completion
tools.description:
After all tasks are done and approved, this tool finalizes the entire request. The user must call this to confirm that the request is fully completed.

A progress table showing the final status of all tasks will be displayed before requesting final approval.

If not approved, the user can add new tasks using 'request_planning' and continue the process.

tools.name: Task-Manager__open_task_details
tools.description: Get details of a specific task by 'taskId'. This is for inspecting task information at any point.

tools.name: Task-Manager__list_requests
tools.description: List all requests with their basic information and summary of tasks. This provides a quick overview of all requests in the system.

tools.name: Task-Manager__request_planning
tools.description:
Register a new user request and plan its associated tasks. You must provide 'originalRequest' and 'tasks', and optionally 'splitDetails'.

This tool initiates a new workflow for handling a user's request. The workflow is as follows:
1. Use 'request_planning' to register a request and its tasks.
2. After adding tasks, you MUST use 'get_next_task' to retrieve the first task. A progress table will be displayed.
3. Use 'get_next_task' to retrieve the next uncompleted task.
4. **IMPORTANT:** After marking a task as done, the assistant MUST NOT proceed to another task without the user's approval. The user must explicitly approve the completed task using 'approve_task_completion'. A progress table will be displayed before each approval request.
5. Once a task is approved, you can proceed to 'get_next_task' again to fetch the next pending task.
6. Repeat this cycle until all tasks are done.
7. After all tasks are completed (and approved), 'get_next_task' will indicate that all tasks are done and that the request awaits approval for full completion.
8. The user must then approve the entire request's completion using 'approve_request_completion'. If the user does not approve and wants more tasks, you can again use 'request_planning' to add new tasks and continue the cycle.

The critical point is to always wait for user approval after completing each task and after all tasks are done, wait for request completion approval. Do not proceed automatically.

tools.name: Task-Manager__get_next_task
tools.description:
Given a 'requestId', return the next pending task (not done yet). If all tasks are completed, it will indicate that no more tasks are left and that you must wait for the request completion approval.

A progress table showing the current status of all tasks will be displayed with each response.

If the same task is returned again or if no new task is provided after a task was marked as done but not yet approved, you MUST NOT proceed. In such a scenario, you must prompt the user for approval via 'approve_task_completion' before calling 'get_next_task' again. Do not skip the user's approval step.
In other words:
- After calling 'mark_task_done', do not call 'get_next_task' again until 'approve_task_completion' is called by the user.
- If 'get_next_task' returns 'all_tasks_done', it means all tasks have been completed. At this point, you must not start a new request or do anything else until the user decides to 'approve_request_completion' or possibly add more tasks via 'request_planning'.

tools.name: Task-Manager__mark_task_done
tools.description:
Mark a given task as done after you've completed it. Provide 'requestId' and 'taskId', and optionally 'completedDetails'.

After marking a task as done, a progress table will be displayed showing the updated status of all tasks.

After this, DO NOT proceed to 'get_next_task' again until the user has explicitly approved this completed task using 'approve_task_completion'.

tools.name: Task-Manager__approve_task_completion
tools.description:
Once the assistant has marked a task as done using 'mark_task_done', the user must call this tool to approve that the task is genuinely completed. Only after this approval can you proceed to 'get_next_task' to move on.

A progress table will be displayed before requesting approval, showing the current status of all tasks.

If the user does not approve, do not call 'get_next_task'. Instead, the user may request changes, or even re-plan tasks by using 'request_planning' again.

tools.name: mealy__get_recipes
tools.description:
Provides a paginated list of recipes with optional filtering.

        Args:
            search: Filters recipes by name or description.
            page: Page number for pagination.
            per_page: Number of items per page.
            categories: Filter by specific recipe categories.
            tags: Filter by specific recipe tags.

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: Recipe summaries with details like ID, name, description, and image information.

tools.name: mealy__get_recipe_detailed
tools.description:
Retrieve a specific recipe by its slug identifier. Use this when to get full recipe
        details for tasks like updating or displaying the recipe.

        Args:
            slug: The unique text identifier for the recipe, typically found in recipe URLs
                or from get_recipes results.

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: Comprehensive recipe details including ingredients, instructions,
                nutrition information, notes, and associated metadata.

tools.name: mealy__get_recipe_concise
tools.description:
Retrieve a concise version of a specific recipe by its slug identifier. Use this when you only
        need a summary of the recipe, such as for when mealplaning.

        Args:
            slug: The unique text identifier for the recipe, typically found in recipe URLs
                or from get_recipes results.

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: Concise recipe summary with essential fields.

tools.name: mealy__create_recipe
tools.description:
Create a new recipe

        Args:
            name: The name of the new recipe to be created.
            ingredients: A list of ingredients for the recipe include quantities and units.
            instructions: A list of instructions for preparing the recipe.

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: The created recipe details.

tools.name: Task-Manager__add_tasks_to_request
tools.description:
Add new tasks to an existing request. This allows extending a request with additional tasks.

A progress table will be displayed showing all tasks including the newly added ones.

tools.name: Task-Manager__delete_task
tools.description:
Delete a specific task from a request. Only uncompleted tasks can be deleted.

A progress table will be displayed showing the remaining tasks after deletion.

tools.name: Task-Manager__update_task
tools.description:
Update an existing task's title and/or description. Only uncompleted tasks can be updated.

A progress table will be displayed showing the updated task information.

tools.name: mealy__create_mealplan_bulk
tools.description:
Create multiple meal plan entries in bulk.

        Args:
            entries: List of mealplan entries, each containing:
                - date (str): Date in ISO format (YYYY-MM-DD)
                - recipe_id (str, optional): UUID of the recipe
                - title (str, optional): Title for the entry
                - entry_type (str, optional): Type of entry (breakfast, lunch, dinner, side)

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: JSON response with success message

tools.name: mealy__get_todays_mealplan
tools.description:
Get the mealplan entries for today.

        Returns:
            List[Dict[str, Any]]: List of today's mealplan entries

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_activities
tools.description:
Get a list of activities for an athlete from Intervals.icu

    Args:
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to 30 days ago)
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to today)
        limit: Maximum number of activities to return (optional, defaults to 10)
        include_unnamed: Whether to include unnamed activities (optional, defaults to False)

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_activity_details
tools.description:
Get detailed information for a specific activity from Intervals.icu

    Args:
        activity_id: The Intervals.icu activity ID
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_activity_intervals
tools.description:
Get interval data for a specific activity from Intervals.icu

    This endpoint returns detailed metrics for each interval in an activity, including power, heart rate,
    cadence, speed, and environmental data. It also includes grouped intervals if applicable.

    Args:
        activity_id: The Intervals.icu activity ID
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_events
tools.description:
Get events for an athlete from Intervals.icu

    Args:
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to today)
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to 30 days from today)

tools.name: mealy__update_recipe
tools.description:
Replaces the ingredients and instructions of an existing recipe.

        Args:
            slug: The unique text identifier for the recipe to be updated.
            ingredients: A list of ingredients for the recipe include quantities and units.
            instructions: A list of instructions for preparing the recipe.

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: The updated recipe details.

tools.name: mealy__get_all_mealplans
tools.description:
Get all meal plans for the current household with pagination.

        Args:
            start_date: Start date for filtering meal plans (ISO format YYYY-MM-DD)
            end_date: End date for filtering meal plans (ISO format YYYY-MM-DD)
            page: Page number to retrieve
            per_page: Number of items per page

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: JSON response containing mealplan items and pagination information

tools.name: mealy__create_mealplan
tools.description:
Create a new meal plan entry.

        Args:
            date: Date for the mealplan in ISO format (YYYY-MM-DD)
            recipe_id: UUID of the recipe to add to the mealplan (optional)
            title: Title for the mealplan entry if not using a recipe (optional)
            entry_type: Type of mealplan entry (breakfast, lunch, dinner, side)

        Returns:
            Dict[str, Any]: JSON response containing the created mealplan entry

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_wellness_data
tools.description:
Get wellness data for an athlete from Intervals.icu

    Args:
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to 30 days ago)
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional, defaults to today)

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__delete_event
tools.description:
Delete event for an athlete from Intervals.icu
    Args:
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)
        event_id: The Intervals.icu event ID

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__delete_events_by_date_range
tools.description:
Delete events for an athlete from Intervals.icu in the specified date range.

    Args:
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__add_or_update_event
hexis__hexis_get_weekly_plan
tools.description:
Retrieve workout and nutrition plan for a date range.
    
    Returns detailed information about workouts, meals, and macros for each day.
    Automatically authenticates if needed.
    
    Args:
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., 2025-10-27)
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., 2025-11-02)
        user_id: Optional user ID (uses authenticated user if not provided)
        
    Returns:
        Weekly plan data with workouts and nutrition information

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_current_week
tools.description:
Get the current week's workout and nutrition plan (Monday to Sunday).
    
    Automatically calculates the date range and authenticates if needed.
    
    Returns:
        Current week's workout and nutrition plan

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_today
tools.description:
Get today's workout and nutrition plan.
    
    Returns workouts, meals, and macro targets for the current day.
    Automatically authenticates if needed.
    
    Returns:
        Today's workout and nutrition plan

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_next_workout
tools.description:
Get the next scheduled workout from today onwards.
    
    Returns the workout details including title, description, duration, and activity type.
    
    Returns:
        Next workout details or message if no workout found

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_weekly_summary
tools.description:
Get a summary of the current week's workouts and nutrition.

    Returns total training time, calories burned, and average daily macros.

    Returns:
        Weekly summary with workout and nutrition statistics

tools.name: IntervalsIcu__get_event_by_id
tools.description:
Get detailed information for a specific event from Intervals.icu

    Args:
        event_id: The Intervals.icu event ID
        athlete_id: The Intervals.icu athlete ID (optional, will use ATHLETE_ID from .env if not provided)
        api_key: The Intervals.icu API key (optional, will use API_KEY from .env if not provided)

tools.name: hexis__hexis_verify_meal
tools.description:
Validate a meal with logged foods. This is the main function to log what you ate.

    After adding all foods, call this to validate the meal and save it to Hexis.

    Args:
        meal_id: ID of the meal to verify (from hexis_get_today)
        date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., 2025-10-30)
        foods: List of food items, each with:
            - foodId: Food ID (string)
            - foodName: Food name (string)
            - quantity: Quantity (float)
            - portion: {"unit": "g", "value": 100.0, "name": "grams"}
            - macros: {"fat": 10.0, "protein": 20.0, "carb": 30.0, "energy": 300.0}
            - dataOrigin: "PASSIO" or "CUSTOM" or "USDA"
        carb_code: Optional carb code (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)
        time: Optional time in HH:MM:SS format (uses current time if not provided)
        skipped: Set to true if meal was skipped

    Returns:
        Meal verification details

tools.name: hexis__hexis_update_verified_meal
tools.description:
Update an already verified meal with new food logs.

    Use this to modify foods in an already validated meal.

    Args:
        meal_id: ID of the meal to update
        date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format
        foods: Updated list of food items (same format as hexis_verify_meal)
        carb_code: Optional carb code (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)
        time: Optional time in HH:MM:SS format
        skipped: Set to true if meal was skipped

    Returns:
        Updated meal verification details

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_food_logs
tools.description:
Get all food logs for a verified meal.

    Returns the list of foods that were logged for a specific meal.

    Args:
        meal_verification_id: Verification ID from the meal
        date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format

    Returns:
        Food logs with basic information (id, name, quantity, portion)

tools.name: hexis__hexis_search_recipes
tools.description:
Search for recipes in the Hexis database.

    Find meal ideas and recipes with basic information.

    Args:
        query: Search query (e.g., "chicken", "pasta", "breakfast")
        page: Page number for pagination (default: 1)

    Returns:
        List of recipes with id, name, description, imageUrl, and tags

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_recipe
tools.description:
Get detailed information about a specific recipe.

    Args:
        recipe_id: Recipe ID from hexis_search_recipes

    Returns:
        Recipe details with id, name, description, imageUrl, and tags

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_custom_foods
tools.description:
Get all custom foods created by the user.

    Returns list of custom foods with their basic nutrition data.

    Returns:
        List of custom foods with id, foodName, macros, serving details and
        serving size options

tools.name: hexis__hexis_create_custom_food
tools.description:
Create a new custom food in your Hexis account.

    Use this when you can't find a food in the database and want to add it manually.

    Args:
        food_name: Name of the food (e.g., "Compote de pomme maison")
        serving_value: Size of one serving (e.g., 100.0 for 100g)
        serving_name: Name of the serving (e.g., "100 grams", "1 cup")
        serving_unit: Unit of the serving (e.g., "g", "ml", "cup")
        protein: Protein in grams per serving
        carb: Carbohydrates in grams per serving
        fat: Fat in grams per serving
        energy: Energy in kcal per serving
        image: Optional image URL for the food

    Returns:
        Created custom food with id and all details

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_meal_inspiration
tools.description:
Get meal inspiration and suggestions from Hexis.

    Note: This endpoint currently returns minimal data from the API.

    Args:
        meal_type: Type of meal (BREAKFAST/LUNCH/DINNER/SNACK)
        carb_code: Carb level (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)

    Returns:
        Meal inspiration data (currently limited)

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_nutrition_trend
tools.description:
Get nutrition and fuel plan trends over time.

    Analyze logged macro trends across multiple days.

    Args:
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format

    Returns:
        Daily nutrition data with logged macros

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_workout_details
tools.description:
Get detailed information about a specific workout.

    Args:
        workout_id: Workout ID
        date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format

    Returns:
        Detailed workout information

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_workouts_by_month
tools.description:
Get all workouts for a specific month.

    Args:
        date: Any date in the month (YYYY-MM-DD format)

    Returns:
        List of all workouts in that month

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_user_profile
tools.description:
Get the current user's profile information.

    Returns user details, goals, and basic info.

    Returns:
        User profile data with id, email, firstName, lastName, sex, height, heightUnit, weight, weightUnit, goal

tools.name: hexis__hexis_get_body_fat_trend

Get body fat percentage trend over time.

    Track body fat percentage changes across a date range.

    Args:
        start_date: Start date in YYYY-MM-DD format
        end_date: End date in YYYY-MM-DD format

    Returns:
        Body fat percentage measurements (value only)

tools.description: Get current air quality data

tools.name: OpenWeatherMap__get-location-info
tools.description: Get location information from coordinates (reverse geocoding)

tools.name: spotify__saveOrRemoveAlbumForUser
tools.description: Save or remove albums from the user's "Your Music" library

action.description: Action to perform: save or remove albums

tools.name: spotify__checkUsersSavedAlbums
tools.description: Check if albums are saved in the user's "Your Music" library

albumIds.description: Array of Spotify album IDs to check (max 20)

tools.name: OpenWeatherMap__get-current-weather
tools.description: Get current weather conditions for a location

units.description: Temperature units: metric (Celsius), imperial (Fahrenheit), or standard (Kelvin)

tools.name: OpenWeatherMap__get-onecall-weather
tools.description: Get comprehensive weather data (current + 7-day forecast)

units.description: Temperature units: metric (Celsius), imperial (Fahrenheit), or standard (Kelvin)

exclude.description: Parts of weather data to exclude from the response

tools.name: OpenWeatherMap__get-air-pollution
tools.description: Get air quality index and pollution data

tools.name: OpenWeatherMap__geocode-location
tools.description: Convert location name to coordinates or vice versa

query.description: Location name, zip code, or address to geocode

limit.description: Maximum number of results to return (default: 5)

tools.name: strava__get-athlete-profile
tools.description: Fetches the profile information for the authenticated athlete, including their unique numeric ID needed for other tools like get-athlete-stats.

tools.name: strava__get-athlete-stats
tools.description: Fetches the activity statistics (recent, YTD, all-time) for a specific athlete using their ID. Requires the athleteId obtained from the get-athlete-profile tool.

athleteId.description: The unique identifier of the athlete to fetch stats for. Obtain this ID first by calling the get-athlete-profile tool.

tools.name: strava__get-activity-details
tools.description: Fetches detailed information about a specific activity using its ID.

activityId.description: The unique identifier of the activity to fetch details for.

tools.name: strava__get-recent-activities
tools.description: Fetches the most recent activities for the authenticated athlete.

tools.name: strava__list-athlete-clubs
tools.description: Lists the clubs the authenticated athlete is a member of.

tools.name: strava__get-segment
tools.description: Fetches detailed information about a specific segment using its ID.

segmentId.description: The unique identifier of the segment to fetch.

tools.name: strava__explore-segments
tools.description: Searches for popular segments within a given geographical area.

bounds.description: The geographical area to search, specified as a comma-separated string: south_west_lat,south_west_lng,north_east_lat,north_east_lng

activityType.description: Filter segments by activity type (optional: 'running' or 'riding').

minCat.description: Filter by minimum climb category (optional, 0-5). Requires riding activityType.

maxCat.description: Filter by maximum climb category (optional, 0-5). Requires riding activityType.

tools.name: strava__star-segment
tools.description: Stars or unstars a specific segment for the authenticated athlete.

segmentId.description: The unique identifier of the segment to star or unstar.

starred.description: Set to true to star the segment, false to unstar it.

tools.name: strava__get-segment-effort
tools.description: Fetches detailed information about a specific segment effort using its ID.

effortId.description: The unique identifier of the segment effort to fetch.

tools.name: strava__list-segment-efforts
tools.description: Lists the authenticated athlete's efforts on a specific segment, optionally filtering by date.

segmentId.description: The ID of the segment for which to list efforts.

startDateLocal.description: Filter efforts starting after this ISO 8601 date-time (optional).

endDateLocal.description: Filter efforts ending before this ISO 8601 date-time (optional).

perPage.description: Number of efforts to return per page (default: 30, max: 200).

tools.name: strava__list-athlete-routes
tools.description: Lists the routes created by the authenticated athlete, with pagination.

tools.name: strava__get-route
tools.description: Fetches detailed information about a specific route using its ID.

routeId.description: The unique identifier of the route to fetch.

tools.name: strava__export-route-gpx
tools.description: Exports a specific Strava route in GPX format and saves it to a pre-configured local directory.

routeId.description: The ID of the Strava route to export.

tools.name: strava__export-route-tcx
tools.description: Exports a specific Strava route in TCX format and saves it to a pre-configured local directory.

routeId.description: The ID of the Strava route to export.

tools.name: strava__list-starred-segments
tools.description: Lists the segments starred by the authenticated athlete.

tools.name: strava__get-activity-laps
tools.description:
Retrieves detailed lap data for a specific Strava activity.

Use Cases:
- Get complete lap data including timestamps, speeds, and metrics
- Access raw values for detailed analysis or visualization
- Extract specific lap metrics for comparison or tracking

Parameters:
- id (required): The unique identifier of the Strava activity.

Output Format:
Returns both a human-readable summary and complete JSON data for each lap, including:
1. A text summary with formatted metrics
2. Raw lap data containing all fields from the Strava API:
   - Unique lap ID and indices
   - Timestamps (start_date, start_date_local)
   - Distance and timing metrics
   - Speed metrics (average and max)
   - Performance metrics (heart rate, cadence, power if available)
   - Elevation data
   - Resource state information
   - Activity and athlete references

Notes:
- Requires activity:read scope for public/followers activities, activity:read_all for private activities
- Returns complete data as received from Strava API without omissions
- All numeric values are preserved in their original precision

id.description: The identifier of the activity to fetch laps for.

tools.name: strava__get-athlete-zones
tools.description:
Retrieves the authenticated athlete's configured heart rate and power zones.

Output includes both a formatted summary and the raw JSON data.

tools.name: strava__get-activity-streams
tools.description:
Retrieves detailed time-series data streams from a Strava activity. Perfect for analyzing workout metrics, visualizing routes, or performing detailed activity analysis.

Key Features:
1. Multiple Data Types: Access various metrics like heart rate, power, speed, GPS coordinates, etc.
2. Flexible Resolution: Choose data density from low (~100 points) to high (~10000 points)
3. Smart Pagination: Get data in manageable chunks or all at once
4. Rich Statistics: Includes min/max/avg for numeric streams
5. Formatted Output: Data is processed into human and LLM-friendly formats

Common Use Cases:
- Analyzing workout intensity through heart rate zones
- Calculating power metrics for cycling activities
- Visualizing route data using GPS coordinates
- Analyzing pace and elevation changes
- Detailed segment analysis

Output Format:
1. Metadata: Activity overview, available streams, data points
2. Statistics: Summary stats for each stream type (max/min/avg where applicable)
3. Stream Data: Actual time-series data, formatted for easy use

Notes:
- Requires activity:read scope
- Not all streams are available for all activities
- Older activities might have limited data
- Large activities are automatically paginated to handle size limits

id.description: The Strava activity identifier to fetch streams for. This can be obtained from activity URLs or the get-activities tool.

types.description:
Array of stream types to fetch. Available types:
- time: Time in seconds from start
- distance: Distance in meters from start
- latlng: Array of [latitude, longitude] pairs
- altitude: Elevation in meters
- velocity_smooth: Smoothed speed in meters/second
- heartrate: Heart rate in beats per minute
- cadence: Cadence in revolutions per minute
- watts: Power output in watts
- temp: Temperature in Celsius
- moving: Boolean indicating if moving
- grade_smooth: Road grade as percentage

resolution.description:
Optional data resolution. Affects number of data points returned:
- low: ~100 points
- medium: ~1000 points
- high: ~10000 points
Default varies based on activity length.

series_type.description:
Optional base series type for the streams:
- time: Data points are indexed by time (seconds from start)
- distance: Data points are indexed by distance (meters from start)
Useful for comparing different activities or analyzing specific segments.

page.description:
Optional page number for paginated results. Use with points_per_page to retrieve specific data ranges.
Example: page=2 with points_per_page=100 gets points 101-200.

points_per_page.description:
Optional number of data points per page. Special values:
- Positive number: Returns that many points per page
- -1: Returns ALL data points split into multiple messages (~1000 points each)
Use -1 when you need the complete activity data for analysis.

tools.name: strava__get-all-activities
tools.description: Fetches complete activity history with optional filtering by date range and activity type. Supports pagination to retrieve all activities.

startDate.description: ISO date string for activities after this date (e.g., '2024-01-01')

endDate.description: ISO date string for activities before this date (e.g., '2024-12-31')

activityTypes.description: Array of activity types to filter (e.g., ['Run', 'Ride'])

sportTypes.description: Array of sport types for granular filtering (e.g., ['MountainBikeRide', 'TrailRun'])

maxActivities.description: Maximum activities to return after filtering (default: 500)

maxApiCalls.description: Maximum API calls to prevent quota exhaustion (default: 10 = ~2000 activities)
